Article.ArticleTitle: The Role of Adults in Poliovirus Transmission to Infants and Children.

Abstract.AbstractText: We draw attention to a neglected aspect of poliovirus transmission—the likely role of adults in sustaining transmission—which has important policy and practical implications for addressing the perplexing phenomenon of continued virus circulation.

AffiliationInfo.Affiliation: Apollo Hospitals, CBD Belapur, Navi Mumbai, India. drdhanyaroshan@gmail.com.
Independent immunization advisor, Marshall, NC, USA.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Adults who are immune and protected from polio nevertheless can, and do, get reinfected with wild polioviruses and become part of transmission chains. Circulating vaccine-derived polioviruses are wild-like, and adults may get infected and continue transmitting them to children. As the primary source for reinfection in adults are first-time infected infants and children, additional doses of inactivated poliovirus vaccine for children will help to interrupt all transmission chains and accelerate polio eradication.
